Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Intracutaneous and Transcutaneous Suturing of Ileostomies

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were aged 18-80 years, scheduled for ileostomy, and provided informed consent.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised 1:1 to receive either intracutaneous (IC) or transcutaneous (TC) suturing.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the effects of intracutaneous versus transcutaneous suturing of ileostomies on faecal leakage and quality of life.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was faecal leakage within 3 months post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computerised, with allocation concealed in sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to outcome assessors, patients, or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between April 2011 and February 2016, 339 patients were randomised: 170 to the IC group and 169 to the TC group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Leakage rates were higher in the IC group (52.4%) compared to the TC group (41.4%), with a risk difference of 11.0% (95% CI 0.3 to 21.2).

Harms.evidence: Skin irritation rates were high in both groups (78.2% IC vs 72.2% TC), with no significant difference (risk difference 6.1%, 95% CI -3.2 to 15.1).
